ComPAIR  // a learning application

Compare answers in pairs for richer peer feedback

A new approach to an old idea  // vs.

Imagine you are asked to comment on different but similar types of apples. Would it be easier to do this by trying each apple individually or by trying them together? Chances are you would prefer them together. In fact, people perform better when comparing than in more general evaluations, an idea going back at least to Thurstone's Law of Comparative Judgment in 1927.

We've applied comparative judgment to an innovative and flexible learning application called ComPAIR.

ComPAIR presents peer answers in pairs for students to evaluate and give feedback on. By placing answers in a paired context, students can use their inherent ability to compare in evaluating peer answers and use each answer as a reference in commenting on the other. This approach to peer feedback helps students identify strengths or weaknesses that may not be as evident for a single isolated answer, encouraging richer peer feedback as well as deeper critical thinking.

See how it works »
